message.content:
We need to “build” an income‐statement number that reflects the results of all the revenue‐relevant transactions (mostly “Sale” rows, whose “profit” has been calculated as “after tax amount” less “cost amount”) plus any “other income” (here the “Interest Receivables” show amounts coming in) minus all the “expense” charges (which include all “Expense” rows and also depreciation, which is a noncash operating charge).

One way to “reconstruct” the result is to follow these steps:

1. First, add up the “profit” figures that were generated on the Sale transactions. (In our data each “Sale” row shows a “profit” amount equal to sale revenue minus its cost amount.) In our working the 42 Sale‐transactions when added together yielded about 
  1,622,011.03

2. Then, add up all “other revenue” items – here the “Interest Receivables” showing up (even though they are “unpaid” sometimes, they are “receivable” items and count as income in the P&L). In our working there were 36 interest lines which (when added) yield about 
  15,023.57

3. Next, add up all “expense” items – the explicit expense rows covering Sales Expenses, Administrative Expenses, Financial Expenses. In our working all Expense rows (when summed) came to about 
  514,628.38 

4. Also, depreciation is charged as an expense. In our data there are two Depreciation rows which sum to 
  45,753.24 + 47,117.43 = 92,870.67

5. So total expense charge is 
  514,628.38 + 92,870.67 = 607,499.05

6. Finally the “Profit Before Tax” is computed as:
  (Sales profit + Interest income) – (Expenses + Depreciation)
  = (1,622,011.03 + 15,023.57) – 607,499.05
  = 1,637,034.60 – 607,499.05
  ≈ 1,029,535.55

Thus our final calculated “Profit Before Tax” is about 1,029,535.55.

When we answer below in the required json format we write:

--------------------------------------------------

{"solution": {"Profit Before Tax": "1029535.55"}}

Note: (Because of rounding the numbers are approximate.)
